Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, half-listening as my family tossed around ideas for the weekend. My little brother wanted to go hiking, Mom suggested a movie night, and Dad was already making a grocery list. I knew they expected me to join in, to help plan and be part of whatever we decided. But my mind kept drifting to the envelope on my desk upstairs—my only valid ID, which I needed to bring to the polling station tomorrow. I’d forgotten it at home, and this morning was my only window to go back and get it before work. If I left now, I’d miss out on the family discussion, maybe even disappoint them by not being present. But if I stayed, I risked not being able to vote, something I’d promised myself I’d do this year. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I felt torn, wishing I could be in two places at once.
